Authors:
O. D. Clerck, Mark M. Littler, Olivier De Clerck, Diane S.
Littler, Thomas Sauvage, Matt Ashworth, Heroen Verbruggen, Frederick W.
Zechman, Caroline Vlaeminck, Ellen Cocquyt, Frederik Leliaert, Steven T
LoDuca
Title:
A multi-locus time-calibrated phylogeny of the siphonous
green algae.
Abstract:
The siphonous green algae are an assemblage of seaweeds
that consist of a single giant cell. They comprise two sister orders,
the Bryopsidales and Dasycladales. We infer the phylogenetic
relationships among the siphonous green algae based on a multi-locus
data matrix and analyze temporal aspects of their diversification using
relaxed molecular clock methods calibrated with the fossil record. The
multi-locus approach resolves much of the previous phylogenetic
uncertainty, but the radiation of families belonging to the core
Halimedineae remains unresolved. In the Bryopsidales, three main clades
were inferred, two of which correspond to previously described suborders
(Bryopsidineae and Halimedineae) and a third lineage that contains only
the limestone-boring genus Ostreobium. Relaxed molecular clock models
indicate a Neoproterozoic origin of the siphonous green algae and a
Paleozoic radiation of the orders into their families. The inferred node
ages are used to resolve conflicting hypotheses about species ages in
the tropical marine alga Halimeda. Interpretation of fossils as extant
species should follow only from statistically sound morphometric
analyses, using time-series in various parts of the world.
